symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Atopic dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A condition that makes your skin red and itchy. It's common in children but can occur at any age. Atopic dermatitis is long-lasting (chronic) and tends to flare periodically. It may be accompanied by asthma or hay fever.

diagnoses.name: Contact dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A skin rash caused by contact with a certain substance. The substances may cause the skin to become red, swollen, blistering, dry, bumpy, and itchy, depending on the type of reaction.

diagnoses.name: Human Papillomavirus (HPV) infection
diagnoses.description: An infection by human papillomavirus that can lead to warts on various parts of the body, depending on the strain.

diagnoses.name: Chronic idiopathic urticaria
diagnoses.description: Long-term urticaria (hives) that has no known cause. It may be associated with angioedema, which causes swelling in the deeper layers of the skin.

diagnoses.name: Immunodeficiency disorders
diagnoses.description: Disorders that affect the immune system, leading to an increased susceptibility to infections. These can range from mild to severe and can be congenital or acquired.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare, genetic disorder characterized by severe swelling, particularly of the face, gastrointestinal tract, and limbs. Attacks can be triggered by stress, minor trauma, surgery, or infection.

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.description: A skin disease that causes red, itchy scaly patches, most commonly on the knees, elbows, trunk, and scalp. Psoriasis is a chronic disease that often comes and goes.

diagnoses.name: Seborrheic dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A common skin condition that mainly affects your scalp. It causes scaly patches, red skin, and stubborn dandruff. It can also affect oily areas of the body, such as the face, sides of the nose, eyebrows, ears, eyelids, and chest.

diagnoses.name: Nummular eczema
diagnoses.description: A form of eczema that is characterized by round spots or patches of irritated skin that can be itchy and scaly. It's more common in older individuals.

diagnoses.name: Fungal infections
diagnoses.description: Skin fungi live in the top layer of skin cells in damp areas of the body, such as between the toes or in the groin and diaper area. Sometimes, the normal balances that keep fungi in check are upset, resulting in an infection.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Hyperparathyroidism Secondary to Chronic Kidney Disease
Neurogenic bladder leading to acute urinary retention and overflow incontinence
Stroke with central nervous system involvement causing incontinence
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with kidney involvement
Toxic reaction to bites or stings

diagnoses.name: Migraine with aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by recurrent attacks of moderate to severe pain. The aura may include visual disturbances, aphasia, or other neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms may include weakness, trouble speaking, and loss of vision.

diagnoses.name: Transient ischemic attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it's characterized by temporary blockage of blood flow to the brain, causing short-lived symptoms similar to a stroke.

diagnoses.name: Multiple sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that affects the central nervous system, leading to weakness, coordination and balance difficulties, and neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain or the skull vault. Symptoms depend on the tumor's size, type, and location.

diagnoses.name: Hypoglycemia
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by a very low level of blood sugar (glucose), which may result in symptoms like weakness, nausea, and confusion.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition arising from the reduced blood flow in the posterior circulation of the brain. Symptoms can include dizziness, visual disturbances, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear causing severe dizziness (vertigo), ringing in the ears (tinnitus), hearing loss, and a feeling of fullness in the ear.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues, causing fatigue and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition that occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Symptoms can include sudden dysphagia, aphasia, and paresthesia.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). Symptoms can include dysphagia, paresthesia, and in some cases, scotoma and hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: A specific disease that causes the death of neurons controlling voluntary muscles. Dysphagia is a common symptom as the disease progresses.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal growth of cells within the brain or close to it. Symptoms can depend on the tumor's location but may include dysphagia, aphasia, and paresthesia.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A migraine that is preceded or accompanied by sensory warning symptoms such as scotoma. Other neurological symptoms can occasionally occur.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which improves with rest. Symptoms can include dysphagia and paresthesia.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor on the main nerve leading from the inner ear to the brain. Hearing loss is a primary symptom, but larger tumors can cause other neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA produces similar symptoms to a stroke, including aphasia and paresthesia, but usually lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves. Weakness and tingling in the extremities are usually the first symptoms. Can progress to paralysis including dysphagia.

diagnoses.name: Multiple System Atrophy (MSA)
diagnoses.description: A progressive neurodegenerative disorder affecting movement, blood pressure, and other bodily functions. Symptoms can include dysphagia and paresthesia.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, leading to varying levels of physical and cognitive disability.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, depriving brain tissue of oxygen and nutrients, and causing cells to die.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache accompanied by sensory disturbances known as 'aura', including visual impairments like scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes, leading to numbness, tingling, and pain, particularly in the hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a 'mini-stroke', it's a brief period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke, but typically lasting less than 24 hours and not causing permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves, leading to muscle weakness and sometimes paralysis.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Lack of B12 can lead to neurological issues, including numbness, weakness, and problems with balance.

diagnoses.name: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition causing numbness, tingling, and other symptoms in the hand and arm, due to a squeezed nerve in the carpal tunnel.

diagnoses.name: Optic Neuritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the optic nerve that can cause a temporary reduction in vision; commonly associated with multiple sclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: Resulting from damage to the peripheral nerves, it often causes weakness, numbness, and pain, usually in the hands and feet.

diagnoses: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome/Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis Overlap (when triggered by a systemic disease)
Infectious Diseases (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis C, Endocarditis)
Chronic cutaneous lupus erythematosus (Discoid lupus erythematosus)
